description: From Middle English stele, stel, from Old English stƒ´ele, from Proto-West Germanic *stahlƒ´ (‚Äúsomething made of steel‚Äù), enlargement of *stahl (‚Äústeel‚Äù), from Proto-Germanic *stahlƒÖ, from *stah- or *stag- (‚Äúto be firm, rigid‚Äù), from Proto-Indo-European *stak- (‚Äúto stay, to be firm‚Äù) (compare Umbrian stakaz (‚Äúupright, erected‚Äù), Avestan ê¨Øê¨ôê¨Äê¨ëê¨≠ê¨Ä‚Äé (staxra, ‚Äústrong‚Äù), Sanskrit ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ï‡§§‡§ø (stakati, ‚Äúresist, strike against‚Äù)), related to Proto-Indo-European *steh‚ÇÇ- (‚Äúto stand‚Äù).

entries.meaning: Made of steel.
examples: Strained in stel ger on steedes of might.

entries.meaning: Similar to steel in color, strength, or the like; steely.
examples: Wher neuer cessing soyle doth steelebright stuff send out from mines.

entries.meaning: (business) Of or belonging to the manufacture or trade in steel.
examples: East Chicago, Ind., a smoky Lake Michigan steel town that isn't exactly famous for its esthetic splendor even when the sun shines.

entries.meaning: (medicine, obsolete) Containing steel.
examples: To mix some Sugar of steel, or steel wine with the first glass.

entries.meaning: (printing) Engraved on steel.
examples: The best picture I have had yet is the steel frontis-piece to my new book.

entries.meaning: An artificial metal produced from iron, harder and more elastic than elemental iron; used figuratively as a symbol of hardness.
examples: Ocearium st√¶li.

definitionGroups.group: (countable) Any item made of this metal, particularly including:

entries.meaning: Bladed or pointed weapons, as swords, javelins, daggers.
examples: For heom ne may halter ne bridel Bringe from here wode wyse, Ne mon mid stele ne mid ire.

entries.meaning: A piece used for striking sparks from flint.
examples: Of ston mid stel in √∞e tunder wel to brennen one √∞is wunder.

entries.meaning: Armor.
examples: √ûai gun hem bo√æe armi In iren and stiel √æat tide.

entries.meaning: A honing steel, a tool used to sharpen or hone metal blades.
examples: The steill to scherp the schawing jrne.

entries.meaning: (sewing) Pieces used to strengthen, support, or expand an item of clothing.
examples: I haue a ruffe is a quarter deep, measured by the yeard... You haue a pretty set too, how big is the steele you set with?

entries.meaning: (dialectal) A flat iron.
examples: One of them having occasion to use a Steele, smoothing Iron, or some such kinde of Laundry Instrument.

entries.meaning: (sewing, dialectal) A sewing needle; a knitting needle; a sharp metal stylus.
examples: The threaded steel...Flies swiftly.

entries.meaning: (printing) An engraving plate:
examples: A re-issue of the Examples of the Architecture of Venice. By John Ruskin... With the Text, and the 16 Plates (10 Steels and 6 Lithographs) as originally published.

entries.meaning: Projectiles.
examples: The crews at the port batteries were pumping steel at the enemy.

entries.meaning: (sewing) A fringe of beads or decoration of this metal.
examples: A trailing skirt embroidered in what is termed fine steel.

entries.meaning: (music, guitar) A type of slide used while playing the steel guitar.
(uncountable, medicine, obsolete) Medicinal consumption of this metal; chalybeate medicine; (eventually) any iron or iron-treated water consumed as a medical treatment.
examples: A stronger physick is now necessary, perhaps a whole course of steel: A physick, God knowes, that this Kingdome hath been under five or six yeares.

entries.meaning: (countable) Varieties of this metal.
examples: The bars are exposed to two or three successive processes of cementation, and are hence said to be twice or thrice converted into steels.

entries.meaning: (uncountable, colors) The gray hue of this metal; steel-gray, or steel blue.
examples: Falkenhayn gave...to Jane a steel glac√© silk dress.

entries.meaning: (figurative) Extreme hardness or resilience.

verbs.description: steel (third-person singular simple present steels, present participle steeling, simple past and past participle steeled)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To edge, cover, or point with steel.
examples: Hure √æolien ant a beoren hare unirude duntes wi√∞ mealles istelet.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To harden or strengthen; to nerve or make obdurate; to fortify against.
examples: But stil he was so steelde With heart so good, as victor he dead left them in the field.

entries.meaning: (transitive, obsolete, of mirrors) To back with steel.
examples: Nay, a Crystall glasse will not show a man his face, except it be steeled, except it be darkned on the backside.

entries.meaning: (transitive, medicine, obsolete) To treat a liquid with steel for medicinal purposes.
examples: She drunk her drink steeled, with which she was cured.

entries.meaning: (transitive, dialectal) To press with a flat iron.
examples: Tha hasn't tha Sense to stile thy own Dressing.

entries.meaning: (transitive, uncommon) To cause to resemble steel in appearance.
examples: And lo! those waters, steeled By breezeless air to smoothest polish, yield A vivid repetition of the stars.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To steelify; to turn iron into steel.
examples: By passing an electric current thus through the bars the operation of steeling is much hastened.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To electroplate an item, particularly an engraving plate, with a layer of iron.
examples: My large dry-point,...called Two Stumps of Driftwood, gave 1000 copies (after being steeled) without perceptible wearing.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To sharpen with a honing steel.
